nodes.bodyText:
I don't know why this is necessary. If compositeAggregation == null, that means it was never set.
Consequently, a composite aggregation should never be executed for this changes check.
Why can't afterKey just stay null?
If the changes detector is not using a composite agg, the caller shouldn't attempt to iterate on it. Consequently a null after key would be acceptable as it would only be called once.

This is basically a state problem. I need to know whether the "changes query" has been executed or not, that means this is conceptually a boolean hasRun. However, this state is managed by the indexer, not by the change collector. E.g. what if something fails, the change collector doesn't know how to handle failures, but the indexer does. With that magic I let the indexer control this state object instead of having a boolean in the collector.
Having that said, I fully agree that this looks hacky. I will look at it again, suggestions welcome.

Could these methods return IterationResult instead of a map?
It seems we always need two pieces of info:

Are we done?
What is the position?

That might prove a nicer abstraction than having a special bucket position.
Also, I am not sure in what case the bucket processor (when not utilizing composite aggs), should ever be called twice. It seems weird to me as it should indicate that it is done :/.

by moving the afterKey to the indexer - where it actually belongs - I was able to remove the bool and the method to get the key. Note that the key can not be persisted right after the response, but only after the real changes got indexed. This is necessary in the failure scenario.
The "special bucket position" is part of making change collection scalable, it's required if more than 65k (10k in older versions) changes have been found.
In case you have 1 field collector that uses min/max and 1 that uses the composite agg(terms), the collector only adds the min/max aggs on the 1st run, but not on following runs in case the terms collector requires it.
I think the challenge is that we combine 2 different ways of change collection in 1 call.
Is this the purpose of the AFTER_KEY_MAGIC ?

yes
Note that AFTER_KEY_MAGIC is only used if there is only a field collector for date_histogram using aggs, but not if you combine date_histogram with terms.
This is a strange optimization to me. If you only want to optionally construct the compositeAggregationBuilder make it a CachedSupplier that is only called once or something.
true, however I am not convinced a CachedSupplier is necessary. It makes it more complicated than necessary. Note that this is constructed exactly once after _start, so performance does not matter.
Why are you doing this null check? Wouldn't it be better to rely on if any of fieldCollector items requiresCompositeSources ?
yes, that's an alternative, however the null check is more robust regarding bugs.

The only reason it is more robust in regarding bugs is because it is set to null explicitly earlier.
I am not sure that is even necessary. It seems to me that some external thing is knowledgable of the internal logic of this system and is making changes.
The separation of concerns seem to be bleeding across a bit.

I moved the creation of the composite agg part into the change collector, that way I also addressed your concern regarding creating the composite but than throwing it away. The also made the checks a bit easier, although we still need some as you can have any combination of aggs, depending on which collectors are used.
